titleStmt.title: E. T. Taylor to James F. Robinson
CWG8653

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, James F. Robinson: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons, Remissions, and Respites, 1862-1863

body.p:
at Home, Clark, County Ky Feb 23d 1863.
His Exelency Governor Robinson
Dear Sir

Your petioner ^F. M. Bush^ is well known to the undersigned having been raised in the same neighbourhood togeather he is connected to a numerous and respectable family, and has an amiable lady for his wife, and several Babes, He is a young man of ardent temperament and dose nothing by halves he has been a Suthern rights man and in his ardor an inthusiasm Joined the Suthern army, and after a brief but sad experance has had his mind disabused from the radical and dangerous error in to which he had been led and I have good authority to believe that he is hartyly repentant, and has been induced by Gen Roscrans Proclimation, and other causes to return home, and voluntary surrender him self up to the authorities Military, and civil, and throw himself upon the clemency of his cuntry and especially the clemency of your Honor, pledging himself to be Loyal and true in the futer

Yours with high regard
E, T, Taylor

His Exelency Geoveneor of Kenentucky
Frankfort
